comments.content:
Hellenic Wide

EDIT: Ooops, Jan even linked faster …

So do you think it’s stretched or something? Cause the proportions aren’t the same (see “P”).  
Or is the sample pre-digital, so that nothing we find will be exactly identical?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823im_/http:/typophile.com/files/popelectronics_4926.gif)
  
Top: Original sample  
Second: [LoneStar](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/lonestar/)  
Third: [Archive Antique Extended](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/archivetype/archive-antique-extended/)  
Fourth: Hellenic Wide

You could add [58 Rodeo](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/baseline/58_rodeo/) and [FF Zapata](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_zapata/) if you wanted.

Nina, your sample of Archive Antique Extended looks very close, except for the tracking.

Another candidate is the old FontBank [“Hefty”](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823/http:/www.buyfonts.com/value_for_money/hefty.htm)

- Mike Yanega

Mike, agreed. One possible problem with Archive Antique Extended though  
is that it looks like a “dirty” digitization; for instance, head serifs of “U” and “L”  
don’t line up.

Hefty is fun too. Ah, I enjoy this genre :)

_Ah, I enjoy this genre_

[Oh, do you really?](http://web.archive.org/web/20090510035823/http:/typophile.com/node/53395) :-)
Nina, you’re right. The reason its slightly different is probably because there were many metal and wood types in the genre and only some have been digitized.
